Title: ‚ÄòLet us be a pillar of strength‚Äô: Hundreds attend vigils to remember victims of Dundalk collision
URL: https://www.thejournal.ie/vigils-louth-meath-monaghan-dundalk-collision-victims-6879042-Nov2025/
Time Published: 2025-11-18T21:36:00Z
Full Content:
We need your help now Support from readers like you keeps The Journal open. You are visiting us because we have something you value. Independent, unbiased news that tells the truth. Advertising revenue goes some way to support our mission, but this year it has not been enough. If you've seen value in our reporting, please contribute what you can, so we can continue to produce accurate and meaningful journalism. For everyone who needs it. Sign in. It‚Äôs quick, free and it‚Äôs up to you. An account is an optional way to support the work we do. Find out more. A VIGIL IN Co Monaghan has called on the local community to be a ‚Äúpillar of strength‚Äù after five young adults died in a collision in Co Louth over the weekend. Three separate vigils were arranged this evening, with one in Ardee, Co Louth; Drumconrath, Co Meath; and Aughnamullen, Co Monaghan; to pay tribute to the deceased. The victims in the crash were: Chloe McGee, 23, and Shay Duffy, 21, both from Carrickmacross in Co Monaghan; Alan McCluskey, 23, from Drumconrath in Co Meath; Dylan Commins, 23, from Ardee in Co Louth; and Chloe Hipson, 21, from Bellshill, Lanarkshire, Scotland. They were travelling together in a Volkswagen Golf while on their way to Dundalk for a night out when they died in the crash on Saturday. A sixth person who was in the car, also aged in his 20s, was taken to hospital for non-life threatening injuries and has since been released from hospital. Two other people were also injured in what garda√≠ described as a ‚Äúshocking and devastating‚Äù crash. The incident, which involved the Golf and a Toyota Land Cruiser, happened on a road near Dundalk just after 9pm. Post-mortem examinations of the deceased have now been completed and their remains have been released to their families. The two occupants of the Toyota Landcruiser, a man and a woman in their 20s, remain in hospital where they continue to receive medical treatment for non-life threatening injuries. At the vigil in Aughnamullen, Co Monaghan, Chloe McGee‚Äôs cousin delivered a beautiful rendition of ‚ÄòAmazing Grace‚Äô. Hundreds gathered on a cold evening to remember the Aughnamullen ladies footballer. Flowers left at vigil for Chloe McGee Diarmuid Pepper / The Journal Diarmuid Pepper / The Journal / The Journal The vigil heard that Chloe was a ‚Äústellar‚Äù defender in the Aughnamullen ladies football team and at the heart of the team. The vigil was told of one incident where Chloe managed to get a score despite being a defender and jokingly told the management that they could call her Colm ‚ÄòGooch‚Äô Cooper from now on. ‚ÄúThat sums her up and her outlook on life ‚Äì she got stuck in to get the hard work done but could have the craic and a laugh at the same time,‚Äù said Annie Hanaway of Aughnamullen GAA. ‚ÄúShe was a beautiful girl, inside and out, and anytime you met her you were greeted with the friendliest smile and the biggest ‚Äòhello‚Äô.‚Äù PJ Markey, Chair of Augnamullen GAA, remarked that the crowd had gathered with ‚Äúheavy hearts and united in sorrow to honour a life that has been tragically cut short‚Äù. He said the incident has sent ‚Äúripples of pain throughout every corner of our community‚Äù. ‚ÄúIt is in moments like this that the true meaning of community, of being part of something bigger than ourselves, is laid bare. ‚ÄúOur GAA club has always been more than just a place to play games ‚Äì it‚Äôs a family, a place of shared triumphs and now of shared grief.‚Äù He extended his sympathies to Chloe‚Äôs friends who died in the collision and said Aughnamullen GAA club ‚Äúwill stand with them not just today, but tomorrow and in all the days to come.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe are a community and we always stick together. Let us now be that pillar of strength for each other, let us lean on one another, offer a hand, a listening ear, a comforting word. Advertisement ‚ÄúOur community spirit is the very foundation of Aughnamullen GAA club and it will help us through this tragedy. We will find strength in our unity.‚Äù Meanwhile, local priest Owen Gordan asked those gathered to pray for those who survived the collision, as well as the deceased. He prayed for them to find healing ‚Äúboth in body and in soul‚Äù and asked that their ‚Äúmemories of what happened neither cause them pain nor torment‚Äù. ‚ÄúEnable them to rebuild their lives with their loved ones,‚Äù he added. Fr Gordon also prayed for all the emergency services involved and asked that ‚Äúbe comforted when work brings tragedy their way‚Äù. Elsewhere, at Drumconrath Gaelic Football Club, hundreds gathered with candles and mobile flashlights. Candles at a vigil at Sean McDermott's GFC in Ardee for the five young people who died in a collision in Co Louth Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo The club‚Äôs flag was flown at half mast as prayers were offered to the McCluskey family, the others injured and killed in the crash as well as the emergency services who responded to the scene. Some of those gathered wiped away tears as songs were played in tribute to those affected while the congregation also said a decade of the rosary. Vigil is held at Sean McDermott's GFC in Mountrush, Ardee Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo A table carrying photographs of Alan McCluskey was also on display. Fr Finian Connaughton told the Drumconrath grouping that they were just ‚Äúone community of five communities in a state of shock‚Äù. He said while people may feel that there is nothing that can be done, this is not true as the community coming together was an expression of support to those affected. He said he was confident that the McCluskeys and other affected families are ‚Äúvery well aware‚Äù that people are gathering and praying for them. Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo Hundreds more gathered at the back of Sean McDermott‚Äôs GFC in Ardee where Rev Dermot Clarke, Deacon of the parish of Haggardstown and Blackrock, was in attendance and led the candlelight service. Those present prayed for those who died that had ‚Äúso much to live for‚Äù as well as those still recovering in hospital. Rev Clarke said the community had gathered in ‚Äúshock, grief and confused hearts‚Äù. He said the vigil meant ‚Äúa lot to everyone here‚Äù, and showed solidarity to the affected families. ‚ÄúAs a club, as a community, as a parish, we all are one together.‚Äù In prayer, he added: ‚ÄúWe ask you to keep everyone safe and in your love as we approach Christmas, a special time for young children, and when we will have families who have people missing from the table this year, we ask you to give them Meanwhile, gardai continue to investigate all the circumstances behind the crash and issued a renewed witness appeal. -With additional reporting from Press Association Readers like you are keeping these stories free for everyone... Title: Meta prevails in historic FTC antitrust case, won't have to break off WhatsApp, Instagram
URL: https://japantoday.com/category/tech/meta-prevails-in-historic-ftc-antitrust-case-won%27t-have-to-break-off-whatsapp-instagram
Time Published: 2025-11-18T21:31:07Z
Description: Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking. U.S. District Judge James Boasberg is‚Ä¶
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Meta prevails in historic FTC antitrust case, won‚Äôt have to break up WhatsApp, Instagram
URL: https://fortune.com/2025/11/18/meta-ftc-instagram-whatsapp-business-legal-federal-trade-comission-monopoly/
Time Published: 2025-11-18T21:27:27Z
Full Content:
Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking. U.S. District Judge James Boasberg issued his ruling Tuesday after the historic antitrust trial wrapped up in late May. His decision follows two separate rulings that branded Google an illegal monopoly in both search and online advertising, dealing yet another regulatory blow to the tech industry that for years enjoyed nearly unbridled growth. The Federal Trade Commission ‚Äúcontinues to insist that Meta competes with the same old rivals it has for the last decade, that the company holds a monopoly among that small set, and that it maintained that monopoly through anticompetitive acquisitions,‚Äù Boasberg wrote in his ruling. ‚ÄúWhether or not Meta enjoyed monopoly power in the past, though, the agency must show that it continues to hold such power now. The Court‚Äôs verdict today determines that the FTC has not done so.‚Äù Meta, the FTC had argued, has maintained a monopoly by pursuing CEO Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs strategy, ‚Äúexpressed in 2008: ‚ÄòIt is better to buy than compete.‚Äô True to that maxim, Facebook has systematically tracked potential rivals and acquired companies that it viewed as serious competitive threats.‚Äù During his April testimony, Zuckerberg pushed back against the FTC‚Äôs contention that Facebook bought Instagram to neutralize a threat. In his line of questioning, FTC attorney Daniel Matheson repeatedly brought up emails ‚Äî many of them more than a decade old ‚Äî written by Zuckerberg and his associates before and after the acquisition of Instagram. While acknowledging the documents, Zuckerberg has often sought to downplay the contents, saying he wrote them in the early stages of considering the acquisition and that what he wrote at the time didn‚Äôt capture the full scope of his interest in the company. The FTC‚Äôs complaint said Facebook also enacted policies designed to make it difficult for smaller rivals to enter the market and ‚Äúneutralize perceived competitive threats,‚Äù just as the world shifted its attention to mobile devices from desktop computers. The social media landscape has changed so much since the FTC filed its lawsuit in 2020, Boasberg wrote, that each time the court examined Meta‚Äôs apps and competition, they changed. Two opinions to dismiss the case ‚Äî filed in 2021 and 2022 ‚Äî didn‚Äôt even mention popular social video platform TikTok. Today, it ‚Äúholds center stage as Meta‚Äôs fiercest rival.‚Äù Quoting the Greek philosopher Heraclitus, ‚Äúthat no man can ever step into the same river twice,‚Äù Boasberg said the same is true for the online world of social media as well. ‚ÄúThe landscape that existed only five years ago when the Federal Trade Commission brought this antitrust suit has changed markedly. While it once might have made sense to partition apps into separate markets of social networking and social media, that wall has since broken down,‚Äù he wrote. Facebook bought Instagram ‚Äî then a scrappy photo-sharing app with no ads and a small cult following ‚Äî in 2012. The $1 billion cash and stock purchase price was eye-popping at the time, though the deal‚Äôs value fell to $750 million after Facebook‚Äôs stock price dipped following its initial public offering in May 2012. Instagram was the first company Facebook bought and kept running as a separate app. Up until then, Facebook was known for smaller ‚Äúacqui-hires‚Äù ‚Äî a type of popular Silicon Valley deal in which a company purchases a startup as a way to hire its talented workers, then shuts the acquired company down. Two years later, it did it again with the messaging app WhatsApp, which it purchased for $22 billion. WhatsApp and Instagram helped Facebook move its business from desktop computers to mobile devices, and to remain popular with younger generations as rivals like Snapchat (which it also tried, but failed, to buy) and TikTok emerged. However, the FTC has a narrow definition of Meta‚Äôs competitive market, excluding companies like TikTok, YouTube and Apple‚Äôs messaging service from being considered rivals to Instagram and WhatsApp. Meta did not immediately respond to a message for comment.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Peter Thiel's Hedge Fund Dumped Nvidia Shares Just Before Its Big Earnings Report
URL: https://www.investopedia.com/peter-thiel-s-hedge-fund-dumped-nvidia-shares-just-before-its-big-earnings-report-11851890
Time Published: 2025-11-18T21:25:01Z
Full Content:
While everybody is watching for Nvidia‚Äôs earnings report tomorrow, a few big investors have already taken their chips off the table. Thiel Macro, tech titan Peter Thiel‚Äôs hedge fund, revealed in a regulatory filing late last week that it sold its entire stake in the AI bellwether during the third quarter. The 537,742 shares the firm held heading into the quarter would have been worth approximately $100 million at the end of September. While people may sell assets for all sorts of reasons, Thiel joins a growing list of heavy hitters whose Nvidia (NVDA) moves have lately raised eyebrows on Wall Street. Japanese investment firm SoftBank revealed last week that it sold its entire Nvidia stake in October, raising about $5.8 billion. (Executives said the position was liquidated to fund investments in another AI darling, OpenAI.) Nvidia, which dominates the market for accelerated computing chips, has benefited more concretely from the AI investment boom than nearly any other U.S. company. An increasingly bearish outlook for its stock could spell trouble for more speculative AI bets. Some investors aren't waiting for its next earnings report to make that call. Others have outright bet against Nvidia. Scion Asset Management, run by Michael Burry, the hedge fund manager of ‚ÄúThe Big Short‚Äù fame, revealed earlier this month that it sold short Nvidia shares valued at $186 million in the third quarter. (Scion also had a short bet against Palantir (PLTR), the data analytics firm Thiel founded in 2003, valued at more than $900 million at the end of the quarter.) Some on Wall Street are increasingly worried that the AI boom is actually an AI bubble. They point to elevated stock valuations, uncertainty about AI's revenue potential, and a series of circular deals between vendors and customers as causes for concern. AI bulls contend that valuations are modest compared with the Dotcom Bubble, to which the current investment cycle is frequently compared, and remind skeptics that AI investment is being driven by hugely profitable tech businesses. The bubble debate has weighed on AI sentiment and stocks heading into one of Wall Street's most important recurring events: Nvidia's quarterly earnings report, scheduled for Wednesday afternoon. High-flying AI stocks like Palantir, Applovin (APP), and Super Micro Computer (SMCI) are among the S&P 500's worst performers over the past week. Shares of Nvidia and Microsoft (MSFT) fell Tuesday even after they announced a cloud computing deal with startup Anthropic, the kind of tie-up that months ago might have been sure to boost socks. Nvidia shares have fallen more than 10% since late October, when it became the first company in history to be worth $5 trillion. Nonetheless, Wall Street's expectations are still high heading into Wednesday's report, with analysts predicting big tech's aggressive investments will drive a solid quarter for the chipmaker.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: The S&P 500 and Dow extend their losing streaks to a fourth day. Are stocks headed for a full 10% correction?

Description: Over 320 of the S 500‚Äôs components ended trading at least 10% below their 52-week highs on Tuesday, while the index was off 4% from its recent high

Title: ‚ÄòMissed beyond words‚Äô ‚Äì funeral details announced for victims of Dundalk crash as hundreds attend vigils
URL: https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/missed-beyond-words-funeral-details-announced-for-victims-of-dundalk-crash-as-hundreds-attend-vigils/a1646510528.html
Time Published: 2025-11-18T21:17:00Z
Full Content:
Hundreds of people have taken part in vigils to remember five young adults who died in a Co Louth crash Funeral details have been announced for three of the victims of a Co Louth crash at the weekend. Five young people, Chloe McGee (23) and Shay Duffy (21), both from Carrickmacross; Co Monaghan, Alan McCluskey (23) and Dylan Commins (23), both from Drumconrath, Meath and Chloe Hipson (21), from Lanarkshire in Scotland, died in the crash on Saturday evening. They were travelling together in a Volkswagen Golf, and were on their way to Dundalk for a night out. A sixth person who was in the car, also aged in his 20s, was taken to hospital for non-life threatening injuries, and has since been discharged. Two other people, a man and a woman in their 20s, travelling in a separate car were also injured in the crash. They remain in hospital where they continue to be treated for non-life threatening injuries. A vigil is held at Sean McDermott's GFC in Mountrush, Ardee, Co Louth (Liam McBurney/PA Wire) Ms McGee will be laid to rest on Saturday. A death notice on RIP.ie reads: ‚ÄúMissed beyond words by her parents Kieran and Eileen, her siblings Stephen (Laura), Aaron (Chloe) and Nicola (Padhraic), aunts, uncles, cousins, extended family, neighbours, her colleagues and students in √ì Fiaich College and wider teaching community and her many friends.‚Äù Ms McGee will lie in repose at her home in Barnadonagh, Carrickmacross, Co Monaghan this week from 2pm each day. There will be a removal on Saturday morning, followed by a funeral mass at St Joseph‚Äôs Church in Carrickmacross at 11am. She will be laid to rest afterwards in St Joseph‚Äôs Cemetery. A vigil is held at Sean McDermott's GFC in Mountrush, Ardee, Co Louth (Liam McBurney/PA Wire) Mr McCluskey will lie in repose at his home in Drumconrath tomorrow from 10am, followed by a removal on Friday. A funeral mass will be held at St Peter and Paul‚Äôs Church in Drumconrath at 10am on Friday, followed by a burial in Drumconrath Cemetery. "Alan will be forever remembered and greatly missed by his heartbroken family, parents Martin and Bernie, sisters Sharon, Tracey and Kellie, brothers-in-law Conleth McAlinden and Alan Wall, aunts, uncles, cousins, relatives, neighbours and a large circle of great friends,‚Äù the death notice reads. A vigil is held at Sean McDermott's GFC in Mountrush, Ardee, Co Louth (Liam McBurney/PA Wire) Mr Commins will lie in repose at his home in Ardee, Co Louth tomorrow and Thursday between 4pm and 8pm, followed by removal on Friday and a funeral mass held at the Church of the Nativity of Our Lady in Ardee. He will be laid to rest in Old St Mary‚Äôs Cemetery in Ardee. A death notice published on Monday for Shay Duffy says his funeral arrangements will be published at a later date. A vigil is held at Drumconrath GFC, Co Meath (Photo: Cillian Sherlock/PA Wire) It comes as hundreds of people have taken part in vigils this evening to remember the five young friends. Three separate vigils were arranged in Ardee, Drumconrath and Aughnamullen, Co Monaghan; to pay tribute to the deceased this evening. A vigil is held at Drumconrath GFC, Co Meath (Photo: Cillian Sherlock/PA Wire) At Drumconrath Gaelic Football Club, hundreds gathered with candles and mobile flashlights for a vigil on a cold, dark and windy night. The club‚Äôs flag was flown at half mast as prayers were offered to the McCluskey family, the others injured and killed in the crash as well as the emergency services who responded to the scene. Some of those gathered wiped away tears as songs were played in tribute to those affected while the congregation also said a decade of the rosary. A table carrying photographs of Mr McCluskey was also on display. Fr Finian Connaughton told the Drumconrath grouping that they were just "one community of five communities in a state of shock". He said while people may feel that there is nothing that can be done, this is not true as the community coming together was an expression of support to those affected. He said he was confident that the McCluskeys and other affected families are "very well aware" that people are gathering and praying for them. Today's News in 90 - Tuesday November 18 Hundreds more gathered at the back of Sean McDermott's GFC in Ardee where Rev Dermot Clarke, Deacon Parish of Haggardstown and Blackrock, was in attendance and led the candlelight service. Meanwhile, garda√≠ continue to investigate all the circumstances behind the crash and issued a renewed witness appeal.

Title: S&P 500 Gains and Losses Today: Home Depot Slumps as Earnings Disappoint; Medtronic Stock Jumps
URL: https://www.investopedia.com/s-and-p-500-gains-and-losses-today-home-depot-slumps-as-earnings-disappoint-medtronic-stock-jumps-hd-mdt-11851779
Time Published: 2025-11-18T21:13:13Z
Full Content:
Shares of a major home improvement retailer lost ground after it missed quarterly profit forecasts, indicating homeowners are putting off remodeling projects amid economic uncertainty. Meanwhile, strong demand and procedure volumes helped drive a strong earnings report for a medical device company, and its shares advanced. Major U.S. equities indexes dropped for the second straight day ahead of several high-profile earnings reports and the release of delayed jobs data due later this week. The S&P 500 dropped 0.8%, the Dow slid 1.1%, and the Nasdaq lost 1.2%. Click here for more reporting from Investopedia on Tuesday's market moves. Home Depot (HD) stock tumbled 6% to log the worst performance in the S&P 500 after the home improvement retailer missed forecasts with its third-quarter earnings, noting that a lack of storms during the period weighed on its performance. The company also lowered its full-year profit forecast, citing persistent headwinds in the housing market and suggested that homeowners are pushing back remodeling projects amid broader economic uncertainty. Concerns about high valuations for companies in the artificial intelligence space weighed on the tech sector. Shares of Western Digital (WDC), the hard disk drive maker that has drawn attention from investors given its opportunity to help satiate AI's massive data storage needs, fell 5.9% Tuesday. Shares of memory chipmaker Micron Technology (MU) lost 5.6%. Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT) shares slipped 4.4% and 2.7%, respectively, as regulators in the European Union announced that they were launching investigations into cloud computing services offered by the two tech giants. The move lower for Microsoft stock also came as the software giant announced a partnership with AI startup Anthropic. Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) announced a deal with Anthropic as well. Nvidia shares slid close to 3% Tuesday ahead of the chipmaker's highly anticipated earnings release Wednesday afternoon. Medtronic (MDT) stock advanced about 5% after the medical device maker topped analysts' estimates with its fiscal second-quarter sales and adjusted profit. The manufacturer of pacemakers and other cardiovascular devices also lifted its full-year forecast for organic revenue growth, highlighting strong procedure volumes and a positive demand picture across its end markets. Merck (MRK) announced positive results from a Phase 2 trial of a key heart treatment, and shares of the pharmaceutical company jumped nearly 4%. In the study, Merck's Winrevair met its primary endpoints in helping patients with certain heart conditions reduce pulmonary hypertension, or high blood pressure in the blood vessels that supply the lungs.

Title: Meta prevails in historic FTC antitrust case, won't have to spin off apps
URL: https://www.cbsnews.com/news/meta-ftc-whatsapp-instagram/
Time Published: 2025-11-18T20:05:56Z
Full Content:
Watch CBS News November 18, 2025 / 3:05 PM EST / AP Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking. U.S. District Judge James Boasberg issued his ruling Tuesday after the historic antitrust trial wrapped up in late May. His decision follows two separate rulings that branded Google an illegal monopoly in both search and online advertising, dealing yet another regulatory blow to the tech industry that for years enjoyed nearly unbridled growth. The Federal Trade Commission "continues to insist that Meta competes with the same old rivals it has for the last decade, that the company holds a monopoly among that small set, and that it maintained that monopoly through anticompetitive acquisitions," Boasberg wrote in his ruling. "Whether or not Meta enjoyed monopoly power in the past, though, the agency must show that it continues to hold such power now. The Court's verdict today determines that the FTC has not done so." Meta Platforms Inc., the FTC had argued, has maintained a monopoly by pursuing CEO Mark Zuckerberg's strategy, "expressed in 2008: 'It is better to buy than compete.' True to that maxim, Facebook has systematically tracked potential rivals and acquired companies that it viewed as serious competitive threats." During his April testimony, Zuckerberg pushed back against the FTC's contention that Facebook bought Instagram to neutralize a threat. In his line of questioning, FTC attorney Daniel Matheson repeatedly brought up emails ‚Äî many of them more than a decade old ‚Äî written by Zuckerberg and his associates before and after the acquisition of Instagram. While acknowledging the documents, Zuckerberg has often sought to downplay the contents, saying he wrote them in the early stages of considering the acquisition and that what he wrote at the time didn't capture the full scope of his interest in the company. But the case was not about the acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp more than a decade ago, which the FTC approved at the time, but about whether Meta holds a monopoly now. The FTC, Boasberg wrote in the ruling, could only win if it proved "current or imminent legal violation." The FTC's complaint said Facebook also enacted policies designed to make it difficult for smaller rivals to enter the market and "neutralize perceived competitive threats," just as the world shifted its attention to mobile devices from desktop computers. Meta said Tuesday's decision "recognizes that Meta faces fierce competition." "Our products are beneficial for people and businesses and exemplify American innovation and economic growth. We look forward to continuing to partner with the Administration and to invest in America," the Menlo Park, California-based company said in a statement. The social media landscape has changed so much since the FTC filed its lawsuit in 2020, Boasberg wrote, that each time the court examined Meta's apps and competition, they changed. Two opinions to dismiss the case ‚Äî filed in 2021 and 2022 ‚Äî didn't even mention popular social video platform TikTok. Today, it "holds center stage as Meta's fiercest rival." Quoting the Greek philosopher Heraclitus, "that no man can ever step into the same river twice," Boasberg said the same is true for the online world of social media as well. "The landscape that existed only five years ago when the Federal Trade Commission brought this antitrust suit has changed markedly. While it once might have made sense to partition apps into separate markets of social networking and social media, that wall has since broken down," he wrote. Emarketer analyst Minda Smiley said Meta's win "is not necessarily surprising considering the lengths it's gone to in recent years to keep up with TikTok." "But from a regulatory standpoint, Meta is far from out of the woods: next year, major social networks will face landmark trials in the US regarding children's mental health," she added. "Still, today's win is surely a boost for the company as it battles criticism and questions over how its massive AI spending will ultimately benefit Meta in the long run." Facebook bought Instagram ‚Äî then a scrappy photo-sharing app with no ads and a small cult following ‚Äî in 2012. The $1 billion cash and stock purchase price was eye-popping at the time, though the deal's value fell to $750 million after Facebook's stock price dipped following its initial public offering in May 2012. Instagram was the first company Facebook bought and kept running as a separate app. Up until then, Facebook was known for smaller "acqui-hires" ‚Äî a type of popular Silicon Valley deal in which a company purchases a startup as a way to hire its talented workers, then shuts the acquired company down. Two years later, it did it again with the messaging app WhatsApp, which it purchased for $22 billion. WhatsApp and Instagram helped Facebook move its business from desktop computers to mobile devices, and to remain popular with younger generations as rivals like Snapchat (which it also tried, but failed, to buy) and TikTok emerged. However, the FTC has a narrow definition of Meta's competitive market, excluding companies like TikTok, YouTube and Apple's messaging service from being considered rivals to Instagram and WhatsApp. ¬© 2025 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. (04:34) Copyright ¬©2025 CBS Interactive Inc. All rights reserved.
--------------------------------------------------

A US judge ruled that the social media landscape had ‚Äòchanged markedly‚Äô since the lawsuit was brought five years ago. By AP Share Save Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking. While acknowledging the documents, Zuckerberg has often sought to downplay the contents, saying he wrote them in the early stages of considering the acquisition and that what he wrote at the time did not capture the full scope of his interest in the company. The social media landscape has changed so much since the FTC filed its lawsuit in 2020, Boasberg wrote, that each time the court examined Meta‚Äôs apps and competition, they changed. Two opinions to dismiss the case ‚Äî filed in 2021 and 2022 ‚Äî did not even mention popular social video platform TikTok. Today, it ‚Äúholds center stage as Meta‚Äôs fiercest rival‚Äù. While it once might have made sense to partition apps into separate markets of social networking and social media, that wall has since broken down,‚Äù he wrote. The $1bn cash and stock purchase price was eye-popping at the time, though the deal‚Äôs value fell to $750m after Facebook‚Äôs stock price dipped following its initial public offering in May 2012. Instagram was the first company Facebook bought and kept running as a separate app. Up until then, Facebook was known for smaller ‚Äúacqui-hires‚Äù ‚Äî a type of popular Silicon Valley deal in which a company buys a startup as a way to hire its talented workers, then shuts the acquired company down. Two years later, it did it again with the messaging app WhatsApp, which it bought for $22bn. WhatsApp and Instagram helped Facebook move its business from desktop computers to mobile devices, and to remain popular with younger generations as rivals like Snapchat, which it also tried but failed to buy, and TikTok emerged. However, the FTC has a narrow definition of Meta‚Äôs competitive market, excluding companies like TikTok, YouTube and Apple‚Äôs messaging service from being considered rivals to Instagram and WhatsApp. Meta did not immediately respond to a message for comment. Title: Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition Just Surprise-Released On Switch And Switch 2
URL: https://www.gamespot.com/articles/tomb-raider-definitive-edition-just-surprise-released-on-switch-and-switch-2/1100-6536324/
Time Published: 2025-11-18T19:04:00Z
Full Content:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links. Players who own one or both of the classic collections for Lara Croft can score some sweet discounts, too. By Evan Campbell on November 18, 2025 at 11:20AM PST Switch and Switch 2 owners can now experience the start of Lara Croft's Survivor trilogy. Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition has not only been announced out of nowhere for Nintendo's systems, but the survival-adventure game is now available on both consoles, too. Developer Aspyr is behind the Switch and Switch 2 ports for Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition, according to the official Tomb Raider website. The game features everything from the original 2014 Definitive Edition release, including online multiplayer for up to eight people. Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition has a download size of 27.3GB on Switch 2 and 27.1GB on Switch. Both versions of Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition cost $20--there's no surcharge on Switch 2--and there's a special 10% launch discount through November 24. Not only that, but there's also a stackable loyalty discount for people who own the Tomb Raider remasters on Switch. So if you have Tomb Raider VI-VI Remastered, for example, you get an additional 10% off for 20% off total. And then another 10% can be added by owning Tomb Raider I-III Remastered. Developer Crystal Dynamics is currently busy working on the next Tomb Raider game, with Amazon serving as publisher. However, Crystal Dynamics has seen multiple rounds of layoffs this year, and Microsoft canceled the Perfect Dark reboot--another project the team was developing. Meanwhile, a new trailer premiered earlier today on X for Season 2 of Netflix's Tomb Raider: The Legend of Lara Croft animated series. There is no word on whether the rest of the Survivor trilogy will head to Switch and Switch 2. For more, check out GameSpot's Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition review. Title: Meta Prevails In Historic FTC Antitrust Case
URL: https://www.huffpost.com/entry/meta-prevails-historic-ftc-antitrust-case-instagram-whats-app_n_691cbf57e4b073def3ee86dd
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:55:50Z
Full Content:
We'll keep digging -- no matter who wants the truth buried. Become a HuffPost member and fuel reporting they can‚Äôt silence. Already a member? Log in to hide these messages. SAN FRANCISCO (AP) ‚Äî Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking. U.S. District Judge James Boasberg issued his ruling Tuesday after the historic antitrust trial wrapped up in late May. His decision follows two separate rulings that branded Google an illegal monopoly in both search and online advertising, dealing yet another regulatory blow to the tech industry that for years enjoyed nearly unbridled growth. The Federal Trade Commission ‚Äúcontinues to insist that Meta competes with the same old rivals it has for the last decade, that the company holds a monopoly among that small set, and that it maintained that monopoly through anticompetitive acquisitions,‚Äù Boasberg wrote in his ruling. ‚ÄúWhether or not Meta enjoyed monopoly power in the past, though, the agency must show that it continues to hold such power now. The Court‚Äôs verdict today determines that the FTC has not done so.‚Äù Meta, the FTC had argued, has maintained a monopoly by pursuing CEO Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs strategy, ‚Äúexpressed in 2008: ‚ÄòIt is better to buy than compete.‚Äô True to that maxim, Facebook has systematically tracked potential rivals and acquired companies that it viewed as serious competitive threats.‚Äù During his April testimony, Zuckerberg pushed back against the FTC‚Äôs contention that Facebook bought Instagram to neutralize a threat. In his line of questioning, FTC attorney Daniel Matheson repeatedly brought up emails ‚Äî many of them more than a decade old ‚Äî written by Zuckerberg and his associates before and after the acquisition of Instagram. While acknowledging the documents, Zuckerberg has often sought to downplay the contents, saying he wrote them in the early stages of considering the acquisition and that what he wrote at the time didn‚Äôt capture the full scope of his interest in the company. The FTC‚Äôs complaint said Facebook also enacted policies designed to make it difficult for smaller rivals to enter the market and ‚Äúneutralize perceived competitive threats,‚Äù just as the world shifted its attention to mobile devices from desktop computers. The social media landscape has changed so much since the FTC filed its lawsuit in 2020, Boasberg wrote, that each time the court examined Meta‚Äôs apps and competition, they changed. Two opinions to dismiss the case ‚Äî filed in 2021 and 2022 ‚Äî didn‚Äôt even mention popular social video platform TikTok. Today, it ‚Äúholds center stage as Meta‚Äôs fiercest rival.‚Äù Quoting the Greek philosopher Heraclitus, ‚Äúthat no man can ever step into the same river twice,‚Äù Boasberg said the same is true for the online world of social media as well. ‚ÄúThe landscape that existed only five years ago when the Federal Trade Commission brought this antitrust suit has changed markedly. While it once might have made sense to partition apps into separate markets of social networking and social media, that wall has since broken down,‚Äù he wrote. Facebook bought Instagram ‚Äî then a scrappy photo-sharing app with no ads and a small cult following ‚Äî in 2012. The $1 billion cash and stock purchase price was eye-popping at the time, though the deal‚Äôs value fell to $750 million after Facebook‚Äôs stock price dipped following its initial public offering in May 2012. Instagram was the first company Facebook bought and kept running as a separate app. Up until then, Facebook was known for smaller ‚Äúacqui-hires‚Äù ‚Äî a type of popular Silicon Valley deal in which a company purchases a startup as a way to hire its talented workers, then shuts the acquired company down. Two years later, it did it again with the messaging app WhatsApp, which it purchased for $22 billion. WhatsApp and Instagram helped Facebook move its business from desktop computers to mobile devices, and to remain popular with younger generations as rivals like Snapchat (which it also tried, but failed, to buy) and TikTok emerged. However, the FTC has a narrow definition of Meta‚Äôs competitive market, excluding companies like TikTok, YouTube and Apple‚Äôs messaging service from being considered rivals to Instagram and WhatsApp. Meta did not immediately respond to a message for comment. The holidays can get loud. But some stories cut through the noise -- the ones that make sense of the chaos and hold power to account. Title: Meta prevails in historic FTC antitrust case, won't have to break off WhatsApp, Instagram
URL: https://apnews.com/article/meta-antitrust-ftc-instagram-whatsapp-c36b941a372321e4ecd05e83e0db1678
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:46:44Z
Full Content:
Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. Attendees visit the Meta booth at the Game Developers Conference 2023 in San Francisco on March 22, 2023. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, File) Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg speaks during an event at the Biohub Imaging Institute in Redwood City, Calif., Wednesday, Nov. 5, 2025. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu) SAN FRANCISCO (AP) ‚Äî Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking. U.S. District Judge James Boasberg issued his ruling Tuesday after the historic antitrust trial wrapped up in late May. His decision runs in sharp contrast to two separate rulings that branded Google an illegal monopoly in both search and online advertising, dealing regulatory blows to the tech industry that for years enjoyed nearly unbridled growth. The Federal Trade Commission ‚Äúcontinues to insist that Meta competes with the same old rivals it has for the last decade, that the company holds a monopoly among that small set, and that it maintained that monopoly through anticompetitive acquisitions,‚Äù Boasberg wrote in his ruling. ‚ÄúWhether or not Meta enjoyed monopoly power in the past, though, the agency must show that it continues to hold such power now. The Court‚Äôs verdict today determines that the FTC has not done so.‚Äù The federal agency had argued that Meta maintained a monopoly by pursuing an expression CEO Mark Zuckerberg made in 2008: ‚Äú‚ÄòIt is better to buy than compete.‚Äô True to that maxim, Facebook has systematically tracked potential rivals and acquired companies that it viewed as serious competitive threats.‚Äù During his April testimony, Zuckerberg pushed back against claims that Facebook bought Instagram to neutralize a threat. In his line of questioning, FTC attorney Daniel Matheson repeatedly brought up emails ‚Äî many of them more than a decade old ‚Äî written by Zuckerberg and his associates before and after the acquisition of Instagram. While acknowledging the documents, Zuckerberg has often sought to downplay the contents, saying he wrote the emails early in the acquisition process and that the notes did not fully capture the scope of his interest in the company. But the case was not about the acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp more than a decade ago, which the FTC approved at the time, but about whether Meta holds a monopoly now. Prosecutors, Boasberg wrote in the ruling, could only win if they proved ‚Äúcurrent or imminent legal violation.‚Äù The FTC‚Äôs complaint said Facebook also enacted policies designed to make it difficult for smaller rivals to enter the market and ‚Äúneutralize perceived competitive threats,‚Äù just as the world shifted its attention to mobile devices from desktop computers. Meta said Tuesday‚Äôs decision ‚Äúrecognizes that Meta faces fierce competition.‚Äù ‚ÄúOur products are beneficial for people and businesses and exemplify American innovation and economic growth. We look forward to continuing to partner with the Administration and to invest in America,‚Äù said Jennifer Newstead, chief legal officer, in a statement. The social media landscape has changed so much since the FTC filed its lawsuit in 2020, Boasberg wrote, that each time the court examined Meta‚Äôs apps and competition, they changed. Two opinions to dismiss the case ‚Äî filed in 2021 and 2022 ‚Äî didn‚Äôt even mention popular social video platform TikTok. Today, it ‚Äúholds center stage as Meta‚Äôs fiercest rival.‚Äù Quoting the Greek philosopher Heraclitus, ‚Äúthat no man can ever step into the same river twice,‚Äù Boasberg said the same is true for the online world of social media as well. ‚ÄúThe landscape that existed only five years ago when the Federal Trade Commission brought this antitrust suit has changed markedly. While it once might have made sense to partition apps into separate markets of social networking and social media, that wall has since broken down,‚Äù he wrote. Emarketer analyst Minda Smiley said Meta‚Äôs win ‚Äúis not necessarily surprising considering the lengths it‚Äôs gone to in recent years to keep up with TikTok.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut from a regulatory standpoint, Meta is far from out of the woods: next year, major social networks will face landmark trials in the US regarding children‚Äôs mental health,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúStill, today‚Äôs win is surely a boost for the company as it battles criticism and questions over how its massive AI spending will ultimately benefit Meta in the long run.‚Äù Facebook bought Instagram ‚Äî then a scrappy photo-sharing app with no ads and a small cult following ‚Äî in 2012. The $1 billion cash and stock purchase price was eye-popping at the time, though the deal‚Äôs value fell to $750 million after Facebook‚Äôs stock price dipped following its initial public offering in May 2012. Instagram was the first company Facebook bought and kept running as a separate app. Up until then, Facebook was known for smaller ‚Äúacqui-hires‚Äù ‚Äî a type of popular Silicon Valley deal in which a company purchases a startup as a way to hire its talented workers, then shuts the acquired company down. Two years later, it did it again with the messaging app WhatsApp, which it purchased for $22 billion. WhatsApp and Instagram helped Facebook move its business from desktop computers to mobile devices, and to remain popular with younger generations as rivals like Snapchat (which it also tried, but failed, to buy) and TikTok emerged. However, the FTC has a narrow definition of Meta‚Äôs competitive market, excluding companies like TikTok, YouTube and Apple‚Äôs messaging service from being considered rivals to Instagram and WhatsApp. Investors didn‚Äôt appear surprised at the ruling. Shares of the Menlo Park, California-based company were down $1.52 at $600.49 in afternoon trading Tuesday, in line with broader market trends. Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Will NVDA stock crash or rally after earnings? Nvidia set for a record $320 billion move as options predict 7% swing
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/will-nvda-stock-crash-or-rally-after-earnings-nvidia-set-for-a-record-320-billion-move-as-options-predict-7-swing/articleshow/125417929.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:46:01Z
Full Content:
Nvidia stock price prediction: Nvidia's earnings report is set to release on Wednesday. Analysts predict a massive market swing of $320 billion. This could be the largest post-earnings reaction ever for the chipmaker. Investors are watching closely to see if the AI boom is accelerating or slowing down. Nvidia's results will significantly impact the broader market due to its large S&P 500 weighting. Title: Meta prevails in historic FTC antitrust case, wont have to break off WhatsApp, Instagram
URL: https://www.livemint.com/companies/news/meta-prevails-in-historic-ftc-antitrust-case-wont-have-to-break-off-whatsapp-instagram-11763491322549.html
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:42:02Z
Full Content:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) ‚Äî Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking. U.S. District Judge James Boasberg issued his ruling Tuesday after the historic antitrust trial wrapped up in late May. His decision follows two separate rulings that branded Google an illegal monopoly in both search and online advertising, dealing yet another regulatory blow to the tech industry that for years enjoyed nearly unbridled growth. The Federal Trade Commission ‚Äúcontinues to insist that Meta competes with the same old rivals it has for the last decade, that the company holds a monopoly among that small set, and that it maintained that monopoly through anticompetitive acquisitions,‚Äù Boasberg wrote in his ruling. ‚ÄúWhether or not Meta enjoyed monopoly power in the past, though, the agency must show that it continues to hold such power now. The Court‚Äôs verdict today determines that the FTC has not done so.‚Äù Meta, the FTC had argued, has maintained a monopoly by pursuing CEO Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs strategy, ‚Äúexpressed in 2008: ‚ÄòIt is better to buy than compete.‚Äô True to that maxim, Facebook has systematically tracked potential rivals and acquired companies that it viewed as serious competitive threats.‚Äù During his April testimony, Zuckerberg pushed back against the FTC‚Äôs contention that Facebook bought Instagram to neutralize a threat. In his line of questioning, FTC attorney Daniel Matheson repeatedly brought up emails ‚Äî many of them more than a decade old ‚Äî written by Zuckerberg and his associates before and after the acquisition of Instagram. While acknowledging the documents, Zuckerberg has often sought to downplay the contents, saying he wrote them in the early stages of considering the acquisition and that what he wrote at the time didn‚Äôt capture the full scope of his interest in the company. The FTC‚Äôs complaint said Facebook also enacted policies designed to make it difficult for smaller rivals to enter the market and ‚Äúneutralize perceived competitive threats,‚Äù just as the world shifted its attention to mobile devices from desktop computers. The social media landscape has changed so much since the FTC filed its lawsuit in 2020, Boasberg wrote, that each time the court examined Meta's apps and competition, they changed. Two opinions to dismiss the case ‚Äî filed in 2021 and 2022 ‚Äî didn't even mention popular social video platform TikTok. Today, it ‚Äúholds center stage as Meta's fiercest rival.‚Äù Quoting the Greek philosopher Heraclitus, ‚Äúthat no man can ever step into the same river twice,‚Äù Boasberg said the same is true for the online world of social media as well. ‚ÄúThe landscape that existed only five years ago when the Federal Trade Commission brought this antitrust suit has changed markedly. While it once might have made sense to partition apps into separate markets of social networking and social media, that wall has since broken down,‚Äù he wrote. Facebook bought Instagram ‚Äî then a scrappy photo-sharing app with no ads and a small cult following ‚Äî in 2012. The $1 billion cash and stock purchase price was eye-popping at the time, though the deal‚Äôs value fell to $750 million after Facebook‚Äôs stock price dipped following its initial public offering in May 2012. Instagram was the first company Facebook bought and kept running as a separate app. Up until then, Facebook was known for smaller ‚Äúacqui-hires‚Äù ‚Äî a type of popular Silicon Valley deal in which a company purchases a startup as a way to hire its talented workers, then shuts the acquired company down. Two years later, it did it again with the messaging app WhatsApp, which it purchased for $22 billion. WhatsApp and Instagram helped Facebook move its business from desktop computers to mobile devices, and to remain popular with younger generations as rivals like Snapchat (which it also tried, but failed, to buy) and TikTok emerged. However, the FTC has a narrow definition of Meta‚Äôs competitive market, excluding companies like TikTok, YouTube and Apple‚Äôs messaging service from being considered rivals to Instagram and WhatsApp. Meta did not immediately respond to a message for comment. Title: Dow plunges 500 points on fears of AI bubble, waning hope for Fed rate cut
URL: https://nypost.com/2025/11/18/business/dow-plunges-500-points-on-fears-of-ai-bubble-diminished-rate-cut-hopes/
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:36:00Z
Full Content:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged nearly 500 points, or 1.1%, Tuesday as fears over an AI bubble shook the market and traders fretted that rate cuts from the Federal Reserve aren‚Äôt a sure thing. It was fourth straight decline for the blue-chip index and the S&P 500, which dipped 0.8%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq slid 1.2% as investors panicked over whether AI firms have been overvalued ‚Äì extending a rocky tech rout into its third week. Shares in Nvidia fell nearly 3%. The chipmaker is reporting its third-quarter results on Wednesday, toward the end of an especially upbeat earnings season. But ‚ÄúMagnificent 7‚Äù tech stocks have dropped amid fears that AI enthusiasm is reminiscent of the ‚Äúdot-com bubble‚Äù of the 1990s and early 2000s. Amazon, Microsoft and Meta also fell. ‚ÄúAll technology revolutions create bubble-like stock price performance ‚Äì but this bubble is still inflating at a healthy pace with no signs of popping anytime soon,‚Äù James Denmert, chief investment officer at Main Street Research, said in a note Tuesday. ‚ÄúValuations, while expensive, still trade at discounts to earnings growth rates and overall AI market sentiment is mildly bullish and not euphoric.‚Äù Sign up to receive On The Money by Charlie Gasparino in your inbox every Thursday. Please provide a valid email. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Never miss a story. Odds of a quarter-point cut at the Fed‚Äôs December meeting plunged to just over 50% ‚Äì down from more than 90% this time last month, according to CME FedWatch, which tracks Fed Funds futures prices. Investors are looking ahead to the release of Fed minutes on Wednesday. The September jobs report, which was delayed by the government shutdown, is due out Thursday. Despite the upcoming data releases, which are key to the Fed‚Äôs decision-making process, several officials have continued to advocate for a slower rate-cutting pace. That has spooked investors who are eager for low interest rates ‚Äì sending gold futures down 0.3% to $4,062 for its fourth straight day of declines. Meanwhile, Anthropic on Tuesday announced plans to buy $30 billion of Azure compute capacity from Microsoft as part of a new strategic deal. Microsoft will invest $5 billion into Anthropic, and Nvidia will give $10 billion to the startup as part of the deal. While massive AI partnerships would usually send stocks soaring, both Microsoft and Nvidia saw big losses. Anthropic is a private company. Further adding to fears of an AI bubble, Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai told BBC on Tuesday that there is some ‚Äúirrationality‚Äù in the current AI boom. In the case of an AI bubble bursting, ‚ÄúI think no company is going to be immune, including us,‚Äù Pichai said. Bitcoin dropped briefly below $90,000 on Tuesday. Many tech investors with substantial AI holdings also own cryptocurrency. By about 12:52 p.m., the cryptocurrency jumped 1.3% to $93,249.46. Shares in Home Depot plummeted 6% after the company cut its full-year profit forecast and missed earnings estimates as inflation-battered consumers hold off on renovations. While a November pullback is unusual, it could set up the stock market for a strong December and end to the year, Denmert said in his note. In the previous trading session, the 30-stock Dow fell more than 550 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq each dropped about 0.9%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq appears on track to break its seven-month streak of gains. Advertisement

Title: Wall Street analysts are still bullish on Nvidia heading into Q3 earnings, even as investors turn skittish
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/nvidia-q3-earnings-preview-nvda-stock-wall-street-estimates-ai-2025-11
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:33:06Z
Full Content:
Nvidia's earnings are in ‚Äî and Wall Street breathed a collective sigh of relief at better-than-expected revenue and guidance. The stock jumped 3% after hours following the results and ticked higher still during the company's call with analysts. "There's been a lot of talk about an AI bubble," Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang told analysts. "From our vantage point, we see something very different." The AI chip maker reported revenue of $57 billion, beating Wall Street's estimates of $55 billion. In its all-important data center unit, revenue was $51 billion versus estimates of $49.31 billion. Earnings-per-share clocked in at $1.30 compared to estimates of $1.26. The firm also topped fourth-quarter sales forecasts, projecting $65.0 billion in revenue compared to estimates of $61.98 billion. CFO Colette Kress reaffirmed that Nvidia is "on track" for "half a trillion" in AI chip orders during the 2025-2026 period, adding that the number could grow as new deals are struck. Discussing the China market, the executive said Nvidia is "disappointed" in the current AI chip export restrictions, which resulted in sizable purchase orders to China not being fulfilled "due to geopolitical issues." The company did not factor in any data center compute revenue from China in its Q4 projection. Nvidia is committed to "continued engagement" with both the US and Chinese governments, Kress added. Huang said Blackwell sales are "off the charts" and Nvidia plans to "grow our presence in the US over the next four years." The CEO also talked up recent deals with Anthropic and ongoing partnerships with xAI, OpenAI, and other tech companies, including what he described as "misunderstood" hyperscalers ‚Äî a category of AI companies including Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon ‚Äî which account for a large chunk of Nvidia's chip business. Scroll on for the full play-by-play from Nvidia's earnings call: Nvidia's stock is trading up around 4.5% after hours as the analyst call ends. Huang says Nvidia is "excellent at every phase of AI," but that inference is "really, really hard." "People think that inference is one shot, and therefore it's easy. Anybody could approach the market that way. But it turns out to be the hardest of all, because thinking, as it turns out, is quite hard," Huang says. The call is wrapping up after about an hour of prepared remarks and the Q&A. "Where are we working right now, in terms of next year, next year there are input prices that are well known in the industries that we need to work through, and our systems are by no means very easy to work with," CFO Kress says. "There are a tremendous amount of components in many different parts of it as we think about that. So we're taking all of that into account." "But we do believe, if we look at working again on cost improvement, cycle time, and mix, that we will work to try and hold at our gross margins in the mid 70s," she adds. The CEO says factors like financing and power aren't "easy," but "they're all solvable." Huang says the chipmaker is "quite confident" in its supply chain. He says the most important thing Nvidia can do is do "a good job planning." Huang says AI hyperscalers can be "misunderstood." Huang says it isn't just hyperscalers like Microsoft and Amazon buying its GPUs, but other companies across various sectors will also adopt them, given the efficiencies they can provide. He says that investing in Nvidia's GPUs "only improves their scale, speed, and cost for general from general-purpose computing." Huang says AI hyperscalers can be "misunderstood." Huang says it isn't just hyperscalers like Microsoft and Amazon buying its GPUs, but other companies across various sectors will also adopt them, given the efficiencies they can provide. He says that investing in Nvidia's GPUs "only improves their scale, speed, and cost for general from general-purpose computing." "Moore's Law scaling has really slowed," he adds. "Therefore, a new approach is necessary for them to keep driving the cost down." Huang says that Nvidia's customer base can rely on it because of the "depth and breadth" of its supply chain. "The reason why our entire customer base can rely on us is because we've secured really, you know, really resilient supply chain, and we have the balance sheet to support them," Huang says. Huang says that Nvidia's customer base can rely on it because of the "depth and breadth" of its supply chain. "The reason why our entire customer base can rely on us is because we've secured really, you know, really resilient supply chain, and we have the balance sheet to support them," Huang says. Huang says when the chipmaker makes forecasts and plans with customers, it's taken seriously because of Nvidia's balance sheet. Huang says that the company will continue to do stock buybacks with respect to investments. He says all of the investments Nvidia has made are associated with expanding the CUDA ecosystem. It appears the rising Nvidia tide is lifting all AI ships. Following Nvidia's earnings report, shares of other AI chipmakers also climbed. Broadcom and Taiwan Semiconductor are up over 7% after hours, AMD shares are up over 6%, and Oracle is up over 5%. "With tensions growing across the Street over the last few weeks as AI bubble fears have grown and put pressure on tech stocks .... tonight the markets and tech stocks got a pop-the-champagne moment with Nvidia's robust earnings and guidance," Ives wrote. "Fears of an AI Bubble are way overstated in our view...this is another validation point for the AI Revolution and, our view, we are in the top of the third inning of this AI game." "Nvidia's supply chain basically includes every technology company in the world," the CEO says. "TSMC and their packaging and our memory vendors and memory partners and all of our system ODMs have done a really good job planning with us, and we were planning for a big year," he adds. The first question for Nvidia's execs is about the company's $500 billion in AI chip orders for the combined 2025-2026 period. CFO Kress says things are "on track" and "the number will grow." The first question for Nvidia's execs is about the company's $500 billion in AI chip orders for the combined 2025-2026 period. CFO Kress says things are "on track" and "the number will grow." "We'll probably be taking more orders," she adds. For example, "Anthropic is also net new," she says, referencing its recent deal, "so there's definitely an opportunity for us to have more on top of the $500 billion that we announced." "There's been a lot of talk about an AI bubble," the Nvidia CEO says. "From our vantage point, we see something very different. As a reminder, Nvidia is unlike any other accelerator. We excel at every phase of AI, from pre-training and post-training to inference." The AI bubble debate has heated up in recent months. "There's been a lot of talk about an AI bubble," the Nvidia CEO says. "From our vantage point, we see something very different. As a reminder, Nvidia is unlike any other accelerator. We excel at every phase of AI, from pre-training and post-training to inference." The AI bubble debate has heated up in recent months. Overall, Huang unsurprisingly remains a bullish AI optimist. He recently dismissed concerns about AI job displacement by saying that someone was more likely to lose their job to another person using AI than to AI itself. "We are not assuming any data center compute revenue from China in Q4," Kress says, talking about Nvidia's outlook for the current quarter. Kress says the chipmaker remains "focused on building resiliency and redundancy" in its global supply chain. Last month, Nvidia celebrated its first Blackwell wafer produced in the US, she says. "We will continue to work with Foxconn, Wistron, Amcor, spill and others to grow our presence in the US over the next four years," Kress says. OpenAI, Anthropic, Uber, xAI, and others are getting a shoutout. It's been a busy year for Nvidia, which has announced deals, investments, and partnerships with a slew of AI startups and more established companies. Kress says sizable purchase orders to China didn't happen this quarter "due to geopolitical issues" and the competitive market there. She says the company was disappointed it couldn't ship more competitive products to China, but is committed to "continued engagement" with both the US and Chinese governments. Shares initially popped 3% immediately following the earnings release, but have risen higher after hours as Nvidia's analyst call progresses. Nvidia says in its 10-Q filing, released Wednesday, that energy capacity could be a potential hurdle for AI adoption. Building energy infrastructure "is a complex, multi-year process that involves significant regulatory, technical, and construction challenges," the company says. In addition to access to capital for certain companies, the company says energy bottlenecks could ultimately "delay customer deployments or reduce the scale of accelerated computing and AI adoption." She says Blackwell's GB 300 surpassed GB 200 and accounted for roughly two-thirds of the total Blackwell revenue. "The transition to GB300 has been seamless," Kress says. CFO Colette Kress said that Nvidia sees hyperscalers like Meta as a major contributor to its future growth. "We see the transition to accelerated computing and generative AI across current hyperscale workloads, contributing toward roughly half of our long-term opportunity," Kress says. CFO Colette Kress said that Nvidia sees hyperscalers like Meta as a major contributor to its future growth. "We see the transition to accelerated computing and generative AI across current hyperscale workloads, contributing toward roughly half of our long-term opportunity," Kress says. Kress adds that Nvidia is helping Meta increase the quality of its services, upping the amount of time people spend on Threads and Facebook. Kress kicks off the call by reiterating Huang's "half a trillion" in AI chip orders number that he previously disclosed. "We currently have visibility to a half a trillion dollars in Blackwell and Rubin revenue from the start of this year through the end of calendar year 2026," CFO Colette Kress says. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and CFO Colette Kress have kicked off the chipmaker's third-quarter earnings call. The executives will begin with prepared remarks before fielding questions from analysts. Huang made headlines at Nvidia's October GTC conference when he said that the company already has $500 billion in chip orders for the combined 2025 and 2026 period, including orders for its Rubin chip. After Nvidia's better-than-expected Q4 revenue guidance, analysts and investors will likely ask for more details about that projection and whether the number has grown. Thomas Monteiro, senior analyst at Investing.com, says Nvidia's report indicates that the AI revolution "is nowhere near its peak," both from a market demand and production supply chain perspective. Despite investor concerns about mounting capital expenditures forcing companies to slow their AI adoption cycles, Monteiro said Nvidia continues to prove that data-center scaling is a priority for tech companies. Thomas Monteiro, senior analyst at Investing.com, says Nvidia's report indicates that the AI revolution "is nowhere near its peak," both from a market demand and production supply chain perspective. Despite investor concerns about mounting capital expenditures forcing companies to slow their AI adoption cycles, Monteiro said Nvidia continues to prove that data-center scaling is a priority for tech companies. Emarketer analyst Jacob Bourne told Business Insider that "Nvidia delivered another blockbuster quarter." However, he said concerns remain about whether Nvidia can meet demand for its AI deployments. "Investors are increasingly focused on whether hyperscalers can actually put this capacity to use fast enough. The question is whether physical bottlenecks in power, land, and grid access will cap how quickly this demand translates into revenue growth through 2026 and beyond," Bourne said. "Blackwell sales are off the charts, and cloud GPUs are sold out," Jensen Huang says in Nvidia's earnings release. "Compute demand keeps accelerating and compounding across training and inference ‚Äî each growing exponentially. We've entered the virtuous cycle of AI. The AI ecosystem is scaling fast ‚Äî with more new foundation model makers, more AI startups, across more industries, and in more countries. AI is going everywhere, doing everything, all at once." Nvidia said it expects to bring in $65.0 billion in the current quarter, which is above analysts' consensus estimate of $61.98 billion. That was a closely watched number, and the better-than-expected result is likely helping propel Nvidia's shares after hours. Third quarter results Is the AI frenzy heating up or cooling down? No company is a stronger measure of that than Nvidia. High-profile investors, such as SoftBank and Peter Thiel's hedge fund, have sold off their Nvidia stock in recent months, adding to concerns that the company's valuation has been inflated by circular deals and commitments that may never yield a return. Is the AI frenzy heating up or cooling down? No company is a stronger measure of that than Nvidia. High-profile investors, such as SoftBank and Peter Thiel's hedge fund, have sold off their Nvidia stock in recent months, adding to concerns that the company's valuation has been inflated by circular deals and commitments that may never yield a return. How much will Nvidia have to overperform to shake those fears off? For the first time, Nvidia established a "deep technology partnership" with Anthropic, committing to invest up to $10 billion in the AI startup. It was part of a Tuesday announcement from Anthropic that it would spend $30 billion on compute to scale its Claude AI model on Microsoft's Azure cloud platform, "powered by Nvidia." For the first time, Nvidia established a "deep technology partnership" with Anthropic, committing to invest up to $10 billion in the AI startup. It was part of a Tuesday announcement from Anthropic that it would spend $30 billion on compute to scale its Claude AI model on Microsoft's Azure cloud platform, "powered by Nvidia." As part of its expanded partnership with Microsoft, the tech giant will also invest up to $5 billion into Anthropic. "We're excited to bring our models as a choice to Microsoft Azure, and Anthropic will be the first model that is available on, you know, all three of the biggest clouds," Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said in a video announcing the deal. After Huang hyped up the Rubin architecture in Nvidia's last earnings call, the chipmaker unveiled its new Rubin CPX in September. Nvidia said it's a class of GPUs "designed for massive-context inference." Analysts and investors will likely want an update on demand for Rubin CPX, which is expected at the end of 2026. Nvidia announced a partnership with OpenAI in September and shared plans to invest up to $100 billion in building out its data centers. OpenAI plans to construct "at least 10 gigawatts" of AI data centers using Nvidia systems. The companies have said that the first phase of the partnership is "targeted to come online in the second half of 2026 using Nvidia's Vera Rubin platform." Analysts may want an update on the plan's progress. GPU depreciation is a part of the AI bubble debate that has been brought to the fore by prominent investors recently, including Michael Burry and Jim Chanos. But Business Insider's Ali Barr argues that their arguments are flawed. The author of the Tech Memo newsletter writes: GPU depreciation is a part of the AI bubble debate that has been brought to the fore by prominent investors recently, including Michael Burry and Jim Chanos. But Business Insider's Ali Barr argues that their arguments are flawed. The author of the Tech Memo newsletter writes: "Investors have begun to worry that GPUs only have useful lives of one or two years, while cloud providers depreciate the value of these assets over five or six years. An accounting mismatch like this could set the AI industry up for a nasty earnings hit in a few years. This view has become almost a consensus on Wall Street now. It's one of the main pieces of evidence for the argument that we're in a huge AI bubble. The problem is that it's wrong: Even as Nvidia rolls out new GPU architectures every 18 months or less, GPUs aren't aging out nearly as fast as some investors fear." Read his full argument here. The AI-bubble debate is raging ahead of Nvidia's earnings report, but there's nuance to be aware of if you're going to make the argument either way, Business Insider's Joe Ciolli writes in today's First Trade. As Joe puts it: The AI-bubble debate is raging ahead of Nvidia's earnings report, but there's nuance to be aware of if you're going to make the argument either way, Business Insider's Joe Ciolli writes in today's First Trade. As Joe puts it: "No matter where you come out on the AI bubble debate, your next move will boil down to one thing: how long you're willing to wait. If you're an AI bull that believes in the productivity gains that will be unlocked, you might be OK with waiting a long time for that to materialize. Or maybe it's the opposite. You want tangible results now, and that's impacting your investment decisions. AI bears also face a time conundrum: Do they dump positions now and wait for any inevitable storm to pass? That can be risky. As investing legend Jeremy Grantham once told me, on a returns basis, it's just as damaging to sell too early than it is to hit eject too late. So do these bears wait longer and try to time the market more precisely? That can be a stressful and high-risk situation as well. Suddenly, the companies pouring tens of billions into AI ‚Äî and getting the benefit of the doubt for their efforts ‚Äî are feeling the heat. The group, which felt unassailable mere weeks ago, is now facing questions from investors: When is this going to start paying off? And do I want to wait around that long?" CFRA Research also expects Nvidia to beat estimates and point to further progress in 2026. In its earnings preview, CFRA forecasts 18% year-over-year growth and 18% quarterly acceleration, the highest since early 2024. It maintains that Nvidia will need to post revenue of $61 billion and EPS of $1.42 for the January quarter, which its analysts think is achievable. Title: Snapped: Indie Festival Phenom Off the Grid Campout‚Äôs 10th Anniversary (A Photo Essay)
URL: https://www.spin.com/2025/11/snapped-indie-festival-phenom-off-the-grid-campouts-10th-anniversary-a-photo-essay/
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:29:18Z
Full Content:
Written by Danny Klein | November 18, 2025 - 1:29 pm Off the Grid Campout founder, visionary and DJ Mikey Made has been on a mission to foster community in the SoCal dance music scene for over a decade. In the past few years, he‚Äôs expanded OTG‚Äôs footprint from Austin to Mexico City and many points in between. He‚Äôs acquired his own remote festival getaway ‚Äì a sacred outdoor space dotted with Joshua Trees, only 2.5 hours from LA, as well as a new rave-ready warehouse in Santa Ana. Made has also brought The Scarab and The Cloud art cars to the likes of Burning Man, Lightning in a Bottle, Desert Hearts, and more. Each production is ideated and built by Made‚Äôs True Crew, a group of live event creatives (many of whom are also DJ‚Äôs) that come together for each unique build, whether it‚Äôs on home turf or under the often crazy conditions in Blackrock City. OTG events are not about VIP lists or hierarchy. There‚Äôs a palpable sense of equality and open access, which isn‚Äôt always found at today‚Äôs festivals. ‚ÄúThis is all for you.‚Äù ‚Äì Mikey Made From early roots throwing remote renegade desert raves with a few dozen friends, to celebrating 10 years in the game with a flagship 4-day festival, the journey has not always been easy. Maintaining harmony in an ecosystem of countless collectives, artists and promoters is always a challenge, but at the end of the day, the unforgettable sets, new friendships, and endless good vibes till the sun comes up make it all worth-while. From international touring legends, to today‚Äôs hottest trailblazers, to platforming rising talent that might otherwise not get a shot at the big stage, Made takes great care in curating his lineups, covering a wide range of house, techno, and drum and bass subgenres. Keep an eye out for upcoming events on their site and socials. Special thanks to volterock_media and @that.cameradude for the images. Title: Nvidia and Microsoft Just Teamed Up For a Massive AI Deal. Is It The Latest Sign of an AI Bubble?
URL: https://www.investopedia.com/nvidia-microsoft-anthropic-deal-ai-bubble-11851841
Time Published: 2025-11-18T18:25:58Z
Full Content:
Big artificial intelligence deals aren‚Äôt what they used to be. Nvidia (NVDA) and Microsoft (MSFT) on Tuesday announced a partnership with private AI startup Anthropic that will see the latter buy $30 billion of cloud computing capacity from Microsoft and contract up to 1 gigawatt of additional capacity. The first gigawatt of Anthropic‚Äôs commitment will run on Nvidia‚Äôs Grace Blackwell and Vera Rubin systems. In exchange, Nvidia and Microsoft have agreed to invest up to $10 billion and $5 billion, respectively, in Anthropic. The deal expands a web of entanglements between AI software makers, chip companies and cloud operators that has elicited suspicion on Wall Street. Nvidia has agreed to invest up to $100 billion in OpenAI, which vowed to buy or lease 10 gigawatts worth of Nvidia chips. OpenAI has also committed to acquiring 6 GW of chips from Nvidia competitor Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), which, as part of the deal, awarded OpenAI stock warrants that could give the ChatGPT maker a nearly 10% stake. Nvidia upped its investment in CoreWeave (CRWV) when the cloud computing provider went public in March, and, in September, agreed to buy all of CoreWeave‚Äôs excess cloud capacity until 2032. Tech stocks and enthusiasm for AI have propelled the stock market higher for much of the past three years. Those stocks, which now account for a sizable share of the major stock indexes, have struggled lately due to fears about an AI bubble. These and other agreements raised concerns that the AI craze on Wall Street was being fueled by splashy deals that overstate the size of the industry and demand for its services. At the same time, investors have become increasingly concerned that AI revenue won‚Äôt compensate big tech companies like Amazon (AMZN) and Meta (META) for their massive data center investments anytime soon. AI stocks used to skyrocket on deals like the one announced Tuesday, but debates around the AI bubble have weighed on sentiment lately. Shares of Nvidia, which is due to release its quarterly results on Wednesday, were down more than 1% in early-afternoon trading and have lost about 10% of their value since the start of the month. Microsoft stock was recently down 3%, putting it about 9% off its recent record high.
